articles.headline: G-20 Seeks Broader Solution for Europe Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Finance ministers meeting in Paris faced new hurdles after ratings agencies issued warnings about European banks.
articles.abstract: Finance ministers meeting in Paris faced new hurdles after ratings agencies issued warnings about European banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Even as officials of the Group of 20 industrialized nations were gathering here on Friday to flesh out a solution to the European debt crisis, a new challenge confronted them, when ratings agencies warned that globally interconnected banks in France and elsewhere faced rising risks.

articles.headline: For Children of Same-Sex Couples, a Student Aid Maze
articles.snippet: The most important document for determining financial aid for college is a form that recognizes only heterosexual marriage.
articles.abstract: The most important document for determining financial aid for college is a form that recognizes only heterosexual marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took five attempts for one prospective college student and her mother to fill out the 106-question federal form that would determine whether she would be eligible for financial aid. And that was not just because the form was frustratingly complicated. What tripped them up was the fact that the student had two legal mothers — and the form had room for only one.

articles.headline: Financial Planner’s Red Flags
articles.snippet: The country’s largest employer of certified financial planners is accused of putting its own employees’ 401(k) money into underperforming funds.
articles.abstract: The country’s largest employer of certified financial planners is accused of putting its own employees’ 401(k) money into underperforming funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re a company trying to persuade Americans to trust you with their money, the last thing you want is former employees accusing you of cheating them out of theirs.

articles.headline: Bishop Indicted; Charge Is Failing to Report Abuse
articles.snippet: The indictment of Robert Finn is the first of a Roman Catholic bishop in the 25 years since the scandal over sexual abuse by priests first became public in the United States.
articles.abstract: The indictment of Robert Finn is the first of a Roman Catholic bishop in the 25 years since the scandal over sexual abuse by priests first became public in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A bishop in the Roman Catholic Church has been indicted for failure to report suspected child abuse, the first time in the 25-year history of the church’s sex abuse scandals that the leader of an American diocese has been held criminally liable for the behavior of a priest he supervised.
articles.byline: By A. G. Sulzberger and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Citizens’ Testing Finds 20 Hot Spots Around Tokyo
articles.snippet: Radiation from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant may have spread to places where Japan’s government hasn’t even thought to look.
articles.abstract: Radiation from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant may have spread to places where Japan’s government hasn’t even thought to look.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Takeo Hayashida signed on with a citizens’ group to test for radiation near his son’s baseball field in Tokyo after government officials told him they had no plans to check for fallout from the devastated Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. Like Japan’s central government, local officials said there was nothing to fear in the capital, 160 miles from the disaster zone.

articles.headline: A Golden Touch Turns Leaden
articles.snippet: John A. Paulson made billions betting on the housing collapse. But his more recent predictions of a powerful recovery have cost him dearly.
articles.abstract: John A. Paulson made billions betting on the housing collapse. But his more recent predictions of a powerful recovery have cost him dearly.
articles.lead_paragraph: No wonder Occupy Wall Street took its protest this week to East 86th Street and the 28,500-square-foot limestone mansion owned by the billionaire hedge fund manager John A. Paulson. What better symbol of the excesses of Wall Street than Mr. Paulson, who made billions betting on the real estate collapse and whose opulent surroundings stand in such contrast to the million of Americans who have lost their homes?

articles.headline: Gas Boom Aids Pennsylvania, but Some Worry Over the Risk
articles.snippet: A “gas rush” is revitalizing parts of rural Pennsylvania. But it has had ill effects — on drinking water, roads and housing — and prompted worries about the long term.
articles.abstract: A “gas rush” is revitalizing parts of rural Pennsylvania. But it has had ill effects — on drinking water, roads and housing — and prompted worries about the long term.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTROSE, Pa. — In the economic downturn three years ago, Adam Diaz idled the trucks at his bluestone quarry and silenced the saws at his lumber mill.

articles.headline: In Private, Wall St. Bankers Dismiss Protesters as Unsophisticated
articles.snippet: As the demonstrations grow, the different worldviews of bankers show the wide chasms that have opened over who is to blame for economic malaise.
articles.abstract: As the demonstrations grow, the different worldviews of bankers show the wide chasms that have opened over who is to blame for economic malaise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Publicly, bankers say they understand the anger at Wall Street — but believe they are misunderstood by the protesters camped on their doorstep.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: For Perry, Lobbyist Is a Take-No-Prisoners Ally
articles.snippet: In Texas, Mike Toomey is respected and feared for his keen intellect, tough political tactics and relationship with Rick Perry.
articles.abstract: In Texas, Mike Toomey is respected and feared for his keen intellect, tough political tactics and relationship with Rick Perry.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Behind every politician there are men and women working in the wings, operatives who can make calls, fix problems, raise money, punish enemies.
articles.byline: By Jay Root, Ross Ramsey and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Egypt’s Military Expands Power, Raising Alarms
articles.snippet: A growing number of lawyers and activists are questioning the willingness of the Egyptian military to ultimately submit to civilian authority.
articles.abstract: A growing number of lawyers and activists are questioning the willingness of the Egyptian military to ultimately submit to civilian authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers are moving to assert and extend their own power so broadly that a growing number of lawyers and activists are questioning their willingness to ultimately submit to civilian authority.

articles.headline: Online Banking Keeps Customers on Hook for Fees
articles.snippet: Customers frustrated by banks’ controversial new fees are finding out that it is not so easy to disentangle your life from your bank.
articles.abstract: Customers frustrated by banks’ controversial new fees are finding out that it is not so easy to disentangle your life from your bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Customers frustrated by banks’ controversial new fees are finding out what industry insiders have known for years: it is not so easy to disentangle your life from your bank.

articles.headline: Romney Beating Obama in a Fight for Wall St. Cash
articles.snippet: Campaign finance reports underscore a growing alienation from President Obama among many rank-and-file financial professionals and Mitt Romney’s aggressive efforts to woo them.
articles.abstract: Campaign finance reports underscore a growing alienation from President Obama among many rank-and-file financial professionals and Mitt Romney’s aggressive efforts to woo them.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is no secret that the relationship between President Obama and Wall Street has chilled. A striking measure of that is the latest campaign finance reports.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: A Genius of the Storefront, Too
articles.snippet: Apple’s free-standing stores, many with soaring glass entrances and staircases, are a testament to the design notions of Steve Jobs.
articles.abstract: Apple’s free-standing stores, many with soaring glass entrances and staircases, are a testament to the design notions of Steve Jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the architect Peter Bohlin arrived for his first meeting with Steve Jobs, he wore a tie. “Steve laughed, and I never wore a tie again,” Mr. Bohlin recalled.

articles.headline: Fannie and Freddie, Still the Socialites
articles.snippet: Although Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were bailed out by taxpayers to the tune of about $150 billion, they still sent an army to an industry shindig.
articles.abstract: Although Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were bailed out by taxpayers to the tune of about $150 billion, they still sent an army to an industry shindig.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE mortgage business is moribund. New loans are down. New foreclosures are up.

articles.headline: Welcome, Fans, to the Pinking of America
articles.snippet: A marketing powerhouse has arisen in the war on breast cancer — and, like it or not, it is shaping the national conversation about the disease.
articles.abstract: A marketing powerhouse has arisen in the war on breast cancer — and, like it or not, it is shaping the national conversation about the disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — THE Dallas Cowboys just got “pinked.”

articles.headline: To Isolate Iran, U.S. Presses Inspectors on Nuclear Data
articles.snippet: President Obama wants United Nations inspectors to release intelligence showing that Iran’s nuclear program is designing and experimenting with weapons technology.
articles.abstract: President Obama wants United Nations inspectors to release intelligence showing that Iran’s nuclear program is designing and experimenting with weapons technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is pressing United Nations nuclear inspectors to release classified intelligence information showing that Iran is designing and experimenting with nuclear weapons technology. The president’s push is part of a larger American effort to further isolate and increase pressure on Iran after accusing it of a plot to assassinate Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Senegal Curbs a Bloody Rite for Girls and Women
articles.snippet: Over the past 15 years, the majority of villages where genital cutting was commonplace have now committed to stop.
articles.abstract: Over the past 15 years, the majority of villages where genital cutting was commonplace have now committed to stop.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARE HAROUNA, Senegal — When Aissatou Kande was a little girl, her family followed a tradition considered essential to her suitability to marry. Her clitoris was sliced off with nothing to dull the pain.

articles.headline: For Romney, a Role of Faith and Authority
articles.snippet: From 1981 through 1994, Mitt Romney operated as clergyman, organization man and defender of the Mormon faith.
articles.abstract: From 1981 through 1994, Mitt Romney operated as clergyman, organization man and defender of the Mormon faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELMONT, Mass. — In ticking off his credentials on the campaign trail — management consultant, businessman, governor — Mitt Romney omits what may have been his most distinctive post: Mormon lay leader, offering pastoral guidance on all manner of human affairs from marriage to divorce, abortion, adoption, addiction, unemployment and even business disputes.

articles.headline: From Britain, It’s Legoland
articles.snippet: The Merlin Entertainments Group has six new or coming United States attractions, sending a message to North America: We are coming after you.
articles.abstract: The Merlin Entertainments Group has six new or coming United States attractions, sending a message to North America: We are coming after you.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINTER HAVEN, Fla. — The Merlin Entertainments Group is one of the world’s largest operators of amusement parks and tourist attractions, entertaining more than 40 million visitors annually. But the company operates almost entirely overseas, and it has no presence in central Florida, the sweaty epicenter of the theme park universe.

articles.headline: NBC Anchor Broadens His Portfolio
articles.snippet: With “Rock Center With Brian Williams,” Mr. Williams will try to spread his broadcast charisma over a newsmagazine show, a TV platform with a history of abundant carnage.
articles.abstract: With “Rock Center With Brian Williams,” Mr. Williams will try to spread his broadcast charisma over a newsmagazine show, a TV platform with a history of abundant carnage.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is something disconcerting about seeing Brian Williams sitting in front of the television.

articles.headline: Republican Debates Are a Hot Ticket on TV
articles.snippet: The early debates for the Republican presidential nomination are garnering almost twice as many viewers as in 2007.
articles.abstract: The early debates for the Republican presidential nomination are garnering almost twice as many viewers as in 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: In September 2007, Fox News put Mitt Romney, Mike Huckabee, Ron Paul, Rudy Giuliani and a man who was, back then, a long shot for the Republican presidential nomination, John McCain, on a debate stage in New Hampshire. The face-off attracted 3.2 million viewers — the most of any debate so far that year.

articles.headline: Battered, RIM Pins Hopes on Next Wave of Devices
articles.snippet: Starting Tuesday, the company will hold its annual conference for software developers, to persuade them to build apps for new BlackBerrys and PlayBook tablets.
articles.abstract: Starting Tuesday, the company will hold its annual conference for software developers, to persuade them to build apps for new BlackBerrys and PlayBook tablets.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — After months of misery underlined by the declining market share of its BlackBerry phone in North America, a profoundly unsuccessful move into tablet computers and, just last week, a prolonged failure of its service for millions of users worldwide, Research in Motion has a new opportunity to convince the world that it remains relevant.

articles.headline: Amazon Signs Up Authors, Writing Publishers Out of Deal
articles.snippet: Amazon.com, the online retailer, has long competed with bookstores; now it is starting to make deals with authors, bypassing the traditional publisher.
articles.abstract: Amazon.com, the online retailer, has long competed with bookstores; now it is starting to make deals with authors, bypassing the traditional publisher.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon.com has taught readers that they do not need bookstores. Now it is encouraging writers to cast aside their publishers.

articles.headline: Volcker Rule Divides Regulators
articles.snippet: As regulators begin a push to produce a final draft of the Volcker Rule, they face hurdles from an unexpected group: themselves.
articles.abstract: As regulators begin a push to produce a final draft of the Volcker Rule, they face hurdles from an unexpected group: themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators have faced a barrage of complaints from lawmakers and financial industry lobbyists in their 14-month-long quest to constrain risky trading on Wall Street, an effort known as the Volcker Rule. Now, as regulators begin a push to produce a final draft of the rule, they face hurdles from an unexpected group: themselves.

articles.headline: Big Cash Edge Powers Obama in Drive for ’12
articles.snippet: Since the beginning of the year, President Obama and the Democratic National Committee have spent close to $87 million, which is as much as the Republicans have raised in total thus far.
articles.abstract: Since the beginning of the year, President Obama and the Democratic National Committee have spent close to $87 million, which is as much as the Republicans have raised in total thus far.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama is exploiting his early lead in campaign fund-raising to bankroll a sprawling grass-roots organization and information technology apparatus in critical general election battlegrounds. He is doing so even as the Republican candidates conserve cash and jockey for position in what could become a drawn-out nominating battle.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: Tensions Flare as G.I.’s Take Fire Out of Pakistan
articles.snippet: An increase in rocket fire into Afghanistan from Pakistani territory has fed suspicion and resentment among American troops.
articles.abstract: An increase in rocket fire into Afghanistan from Pakistani territory has fed suspicion and resentment among American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE SHARANA, Afghanistan — American and Afghan soldiers near the border with Pakistan have faced a sharply increased volume of rocket fire from Pakistani territory in the past six months, putting them at greater risk even as worries over the disintegrating relationship between the United States and Pakistan constrain how they can strike back.

articles.headline: Pleas Unheeded as Students’ U.S. Jobs Soured
articles.snippet: A group of exchange students sponsored by the State Department spent thousands of dollars to experience life in the United States, but what they got were arduous shifts in a factory and no help when they complained.
articles.abstract: A group of exchange students sponsored by the State Department spent thousands of dollars to experience life in the United States, but what they got were arduous shifts in a factory and no help when they complained.
articles.lead_paragraph: The college student from Moldova was in the United States on a cultural exchange program run for half a century by the federal government, a program designed to build international understanding by providing foreign students with a dream summer of fun in America. So he summoned his best English for the e-mail he sent to the State Department in June.

articles.headline: Wireless Users Will Get Alerts on Excess Use
articles.snippet: Wireless carriers have been losing good will with users bitter about the sometimes exorbitant charges resulting from overuse of what has become a consumer staple — the cellphone.
articles.abstract: Wireless carriers have been losing good will with users bitter about the sometimes exorbitant charges resulting from overuse of what has become a consumer staple — the cellphone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Users of cellphones and other wireless devices who are nearing their monthly limit for voice, text or data services will receive alerts when they are in danger of being charged extra, under an agreement reached by carriers and the Federal Communications Commission.

articles.headline: A Less Risky Down Syndrome Test Is Developed
articles.snippet: The new test may reduce the need for riskier invasive procedures like amniocentesis, but it raises ethical issues.
articles.abstract: The new test may reduce the need for riskier invasive procedures like amniocentesis, but it raises ethical issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: New tests are coming to market that can detect Down syndrome in a fetus using a sample of the mother’s blood, potentially reducing the need for riskier invasive tests while also stirring ethical concerns.
